title: Luzin N property
summary: In mathematics, a function f on the interval [a, b] has the Luzin N property, named after Nikolai Luzin (also called Luzin property or N property) if for all N ⊂ [ a , b ] {\displaystyle N\subset [a,b]} such that λ ( N ) = 0 {\displaystyle \lambda (N)=0} , there holds: λ ( f ( N ) ) = 0 {\displaystyle \lambda (f(N))=0} , where λ {\displaystyle \lambda } stands for the Lebesgue measure.
